Legal_Issue: Whether the Tribunal erred in determining Dr. Sangha had a serious possibility of obtaining the RO position and whether the remedy was appropriate
Application_Facts: Dr. Sangha, a visible minority immigrant, was not hired for an entry-level position due to being overqualified; statistical analysis was considered but deemed insufficient alone
Decision_Outcome: Tribunal found no serious possibility of employment but acknowledged discrimination
Court_Ruling: Judicial review granted; case remitted for reconsideration
Claimant_Status: Dr. Sangha, qualified professional from a visible minority group
Defendant_Behavior: Did not hire Dr. Sangha citing overqualification, which disproportionately affected a visible minority immigrant
Legal_Standard: Discrimination on prohibited grounds under the Canadian Human Rights Act is illegal
Assessment_Factor: Serious possibility of obtaining employment, over-qualification as a factor
Review_Standard: Reasonableness or correctness in Tribunal's legal and factual interpretation
Evidence_Used: Statistical analysis of hiring patterns, qualifications of Dr. Sangha
Legal_Provision_Cited: Sections of the Canadian Human Rights Act prohibiting discrimination in employment
Application_Basis: Disproportionate impact of overqualification on visible minority immigrants
Evidence_Assessed: Qualifications of Dr. Sangha, rationale for non-hiring, discriminatory effect
Relief_Sought: Judicial review, reassessment of employment possibility, compensation
Governing_Rule: Under the Canadian Human Rights Act, discrimination on prohibited grounds is illegal; remedies may include lost wages if serious possibility of employment existed
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Reliance on over-qualification without proper assessment of actual suitability
Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; matter remitted to Tribunal
Harm_Assessment: Loss of opportunity and potential lost wages due to discriminatory hiring practice
Cause_Description: Dr. Sangha alleged discrimination after not being hired despite qualifications, due to being overqualified—a factor with adverse impact on immigrants
Evidence_Handling: Statistical evidence considered but not determinative; individual suitability not properly assessed
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 3 of the Canadian Human Rights Act (prohibition of discrimination in employment)
Evidence_Issues: Over-reliance on over-qualification as a proxy for unsuitability without individualized assessment
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction under Federal Courts Act for judicial review of Tribunal decision
Evidence_Assessment: Tribunal failed to adequately assess whether over-qualification was a pretext for discrimination
Decision_Rationale: Error in considering over-qualification when assessing serious possibility of employment; discrimination acknowledged but remedy not properly linked
Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient individualized assessment of Dr. Sangha’s suitability despite strong qualifications
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious possibility of employment standard in discrimination cases
